config.question: Which of the following statements best characterizes the Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka case?

choices.content: President Eisenhower heartily endorsed the decision, saying that it “set southern progress ahead at least fifteen years.”
The Supreme Court was nearly evenly divided on the decision.
Chief Justice Warren declared that racially segregated public school facilities were constitutional as long as those facilities truly were equal.
Thurgood Marshall argued that segregated facilities were inherently unequal because they resulted in psychological damage, which violated the Fourteenth Amendment.

answer_3.response: Consider This: The Supreme Court was unanimous in its decision in the Brown case. Because Chief Justice Warren realized that changing historic patterns of segregation would be difficult, the Court did not set a timeline, but ruled that desegregation should proceed “with all deliberate speed.” President Eisenhower believed that “cold law making” could not alter people’s attitudes but nevertheless vowed that “the Federal Constitution will be upheld by me by every legal means at my command.” See L.O. 29.3 The Struggle over Civil Rights.
